unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip across India by train? Awesome! It's honestly the best way to see the country, even if it sometimes takes a bit longer. I remember my first long-distance train journey - Delhi to Guwahati, a whopping 1900+ kms! Definitely prepone your travel plans if you can get a confirmed ticket, especially during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations.
normalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip across India by train? Awesome! It's honestly the best way to see the country, even if it sometimes takes a bit longer. I remember my first long-distance train journey - Delhi to Guwahati, a whopping one thousand nine hundred plus kilometers! Definitely prepone your travel plans if you can get a confirmed ticket, especially during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations.

unnormalised: First things first, IRCTC is your best friend. That's where you book your tickets online. Pro-tip: Tatkal tickets are a lifesaver for last-minute plans, but they get booked in like, 2 seconds flat. Always keep a backup plan, maybe a bus or flight. Speaking of timings, train no. 12345 (Rajdhani Express) usually leaves on time from New Delhi Railway Station at around 4:30 PM.
normalised: First things first, I-R-C-T-C is your best friend. That's where you book your tickets online. Pro-tip: Tatkal tickets are a lifesaver for last-minute plans, but they get booked in like, two seconds flat. Always keep a backup plan, maybe a bus or flight. Speaking of timings, train number one two three four five (Rajdhani Express) usually leaves on time from New Delhi Railway Station at around four thirty P-M.

unnormalised: Now, classes! 3AC (Third AC) is generally a good balance between comfort and cost. 2AC is nicer, of course, but also pricier. Sleeper class is… an experience. Always keep your luggage locked, and maybe bring your own bedsheet. The food situation on trains has improved a lot, actually. You can order online through apps now, or just buy stuff from the vendors who hop on at stations. I remember once paying only Rs. 20 for a chai, best chai of my life!

unnormalised: Entertainment is key! Download some Bollywood movies beforehand, or a good book. Phone battery is precious, so carry a power bank. And don't forget your headphones, because sometimes your co-passengers will be having LOUD conversations at 2:00 AM. Respect their space, and hope they respect yours!

And don't forget your headphones, because sometimes your co-passengers will be having LOUD conversations at two zero zero A-M. Respect their space, and hope they respect yours!

unnormalised: Safety wise, keep your valuables close. Don't accept food or drinks from strangers. And be aware of your surroundings, especially at crowded stations. The helpline number 139 is super useful for any issues or emergencies.
normalised: Safety wise, keep your valuables close. Don't accept food or drinks from strangers. And be aware of your surroundings, especially at crowded stations. The helpline number one three nine is super useful for any issues or emergencies.

unnormalised: Some of my favorite train journeys in India have been along the Konkan coast – the scenery is just breathtaking! Or the toy train from Kalka to Shimla – such a charming ride. Definitely add those to your list if you get the chance.
normalised: Some of my favorite train journeys in India have been along the Konkan coast – the scenery is just breathtaking! Or the toy train from Kalka to Shimla – such a charming ride. Definitely add those to your list if you get the chance.

unnormalised: So, yeah! Train travel in India can be a bit chaotic, but it’s also incredibly rewarding. Embrace the chaos, enjoy the views, and get ready for an adventure. Happy travels, bhai!
